response.answer_text: To the people claiming that the USA did not lose the War of 1812, let me clarify a few points, here: The USA has most definitely LOST some wars. And these wars I am mentioning don’t come in the form of the USA simply withdrawing because of some hippies protesting the government and the rest of the population chooses to agree to a withdrawal, despite potentially winning on the battlefield. Rather, you should imagine a war that was so lopsided in favour of the Americans, that their militia alone was nearly twice the size of the entire population (women, children and the elderly included) that they were fighting against… AND LOST!!!  If this type of war sounds familiar to you, I introduce to you, the War of 1812. Contrary to popular belief, the War of 1812 was not fought only in 1812. In fact, if we count the November 7, 1811 Battle of Tippecanoe as part of the same war, then the war itself actually started in 1811 when American forces effectively waged war against the native population, who in turn decided to side with the Canadians and British. Quite ironically, despite the fact that even Thomas Jefferson — who was himself personally opposed to the war — said that “taking Canada will be just a matter of marching” and that even the approval to end naval impressment did not placate the Americans from commencing the invasion anyway, many modern Americans will insist that the reason they failed to annex Canada in the first place was because they never intended to. It is a convenient form of revision to suggest that the excuse for going to war in the first place had already been resolved before the first shots were ever fired, was used nonetheless, resulting in a three year war that saw a total of 50,000 deaths on both sides.  From the archives: Montrealers anxiously followed fall of Fort Detroit The issue of impressment was never even brought up during the Treaty of Ghent, despite being reintroduced once it became clear that the Americans intended to pursue the war nonetheless. Impressment simply ended later that year upon the final conclusion of the Napoleonic Wars. The War of 1812 was not the first time that the USA invaded Canada, and it most certainly would not be the last. In 1690, the USA — then under the influence of the British — besieged Quebec City under the command of future Massachusetts Governor William Phips.  The Quest for Quebec In 1711, a second failed invasion was repulsed when an American fleet was battered by a storm in the Saint Lawrence River, resulting in the destruction of most of the naval fleet. And finally, in 1775, two American forces were sent to annex Canada by capturing Montreal as well as nearly capturing Quebec City, after the Canadian population declined to partake in the American Revolutionary Wars. In order to pull off a successful invasion, the Americans went so far as to recruit Canadian inhabitants to join their army, forming the First Canadian Regiment, which would later take part in several campaigns in the American theatre in the aftermath of the failed 1775 invasion of Canada.  1775-1781: Revolting People and Benedict Arnold & Other Quebec Curios There is a popular misconception amongst most Americans as well as many Canadians who are ignorant of the past that Canada did not exist during the War of 1812. However, Canada had been referenced as a recognisable identity in its own right since at least the days of Jacques Cartier and Samuel de Champlain. The Saint Lawrence was the main natural boundary, with Canada being the lands north of the river, while “America” was the natural terrain located south of the Saint Lawrence. In 1791, Canada was broken into lower and upper Canada, and in 1841, upper and lower Canada were morphed into the Dominion (Province) of Canada. It was not until 1867, when Canada’s political system became federal that the name was once again changed to simply Canada; a name that has since remained.  The Canadas - Wikipedia Despite many of their names being changed, most of Canada’s major military units were around during the eighteenth century, long before the War of 1812 ever made its way into the history books. Most of these military units would also see action during the War of 1812, as well as all the subsequent wars Canada would face in the decades and centuries to come. Canada’s timing in becoming a federal entity, was, quite ironically speaking from those claiming that the USA had no interest in annexing Canada, the result of the Americans attempting to justify an invasion before, during and even after the conclusion of the American Civil War.  Canadian units of the War of 1812 - Wikipedia Since it was customary for Canadians aspiring for a military career to serve in foreign armies, some 60,000 Canadians participated in the American Civil War in the event that these veterans would later be needed for the defence of their own country. A link to Canada’s forgotten involvement in the American Civil War can be found in another answer I have written, where Canadians were even blamed for the assassination of Abraham Lincoln, due to John Wilkes Booth plotting his assassination while he was living in Montreal. The fact that Jefferson Davis and his family fled to Canada as refugees also played a role in compiling “evidence” to support a renewed war against Canada.  David Frigault's answer to What role did Canada play in the American Civil War? Even into the twentieth century, the USA had plotted several other invasions plans, including one infamous plan which is now nicknamed “War Plan Red.” Many historians also believe that had World War Two not commenced when it did, British and American relations would have deteriorated to the point that another war would have broken out in North America between the United States and its colonies versus the British Empire. Despite the fact that Americans defend the War of 1812 as a war to end British impressment, this dubious excuse is like claiming that the Trojan Wars was the result of Paris capturing Helen of Troy and angering Agamemnon, or the claim that the War of Jenkin’s war was the result of a sea captain getting his ear mutilated; or that the American Revolutionary War was the result of the Boston Tea Party; or that World War One was the result of the assassination of the Archduke Ferdinand and his wife.  Had the British declined to end impressment until after hostilities had started, then the proponents of the impressment theory would at least have had a half-decent argument to be made, as we could then have a debate regarding whether or not the British would have ended impressment on their own without the need to wage war. Nonetheless, despite the fact that news of the abolition of impressment was delayed, due to the unexpected assassination of British Prime Minister Spencer Perceval on May 11, 1812, the war itself — with the possible exception of a few individuals dying of disease or other natural causes — remained completely bloodless up until the Siege of Detroit in August 1812, two months after the United States has formally declared war against Britain.  The Assassination of the Prime Minister, Spencer Perceval Ultimately, the justification of war by means of ending impressment was just a convenient excuse made by the war hawks of the day who were egging for a new fight against Britain in the same way that the previous generation had done. This excuse is similar to those who today say that the American Civil War was fought over slavery, when in fact Abraham Lincoln made it clear in a presidential address that he was not willing to wage a war in order to abolish slavery. The Emancipation Proclamation also did not apply to states such as Kentucky, Maryland, Missouri, Delaware or any other area that was under union control at the time the proclamation came into effect, nor did it apply to certain confederate states, such as Tennessee, which were given immunity to the Emancipation Proclamation for economic reasons.  Impressment Of American Sailors by Granger 5 Things You May Not Know About Lincoln, Slavery and Emancipation If the war was about freeing the slaves, the Emancipation alone should have ended it, as it clearly stated that territories or confederate states that surrendered before it came into effect would not lose their slaves. As General Grant of the Union once said himself: “If the war was about freeing the slaves, I would draw my sword for the other side.” Grant himself had a personal background history regarding slavery in his home state of Delaware — one of four union states that had slavery during the war, and also one of the few states which continued to practice it until it was formally abolished at the state level in 1868. Despite freeing his own slaves, Grant also believed that the Union Government would be acting out of proportion if it was willing to wage a war over the issues regarding slavery.  The Shadow of a Shade: General Grant and Not Fighting for Abolition - This Cruel War The same myth about slavery in the civil war has now been used with impressment to justify a war against Canada. Another interesting myth is that Canada and Britain came down to Washington with the aim of destroying the White House for tyrannical purposes. What American “historians” seem to omit is the fact that the Americans, the year prior, sacked the city of York (modern Toronto), which was also the capital at the time of the war.  Battle of York - Wikipedia Unlike in the burning of the White House, where only government buildings were targeted, American soldiers at York razed the ENTIRE city, and an untold number of civilians who could not escape the fire were burned to death. During the actual looting of farmlands and personal belongings, some Canadian civilians were reportedly shot by American soldiers, and their behaviour is said to have been so vile during the two days of plundering that even some of their own senior commanders — including Henry Dearborn — became outraged.  Henry Dearborn - Wikipedia Needless to say, the destruction of Washington was quite tame on the part of the British and Canadians compared to what happened at York, and if not for the fact that a tornado came down that night and destroyed hundreds of homes (as well as killing five British soldiers who were stationed in the city that night) then the whole incident would be seen as hardly more than a footnote in the history of the War of 1812, as Washington itself would have remained far better preserved… …Unlike York.  The British Burn Washington, D.C., 200 Years Ago https://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/the-tornado-that-saved-washington-33901211/ Many Canadian artifacts have either never been returned, or have since been lost. The Canadian Mace, which was taken from the Legislative Assembly during the Burning of York, was only returned in 1934 by President Franklin Roosevelt in an effort to try and reconcile his country with the British Empire. Seeing as there is overwhelming evidence that the United States did try to annex Canada during the war and failed to do so, is as good of an indication as any that the United States did in fact LOSE the war.  Treaty of Ghent - Wikipedia Part of the Treaty of Ghent was that the United States would be allowed to retain Carleton Island (the only land change during the war) as the United States was not willing to give it up for free, and the British did not find the island valuable enough to continue fighting a war over it. Had the war not been about annexation, the question about regarding annexation of Carleton Island would never have been an issue brought up during the treaty, and the island would be part of Canadian soil today! One of the most mythical battles of the war, however, has to be the Battle of New Orleans. In American folklore, it is alleged that the British sustained such a crushing defeat, that in one afternoon alone, the Americans inflicted no fewer than 2,000 casualties on the advancing British. The reality, of course, is that number is more than the historical number of British who died during the ENTIRE war, including at sea and in the Canadian theatre. It is estimated that 1,600 British soldiers were killed in action, and that most of them were not sustained while fighting on American soil.  Battle of New Orleans - Wikipedia Battle of New Orleans The “Battle of New Orleans” was actually a three week campaign, consisting of five separate battles, as well as dozens of engagements and skirmishes. The British never even arrived at New Orleans. The walls of Chalmette, located five kilometres from New Orleans, was the closest that the British got to, and the actual size of the attack was mild compared to the embellished version later promoted in American history books. Over a period of three weeks, the British took 316 dead and 700 injured over multiple battles and countless firefights consisting of squads or rearguard actions. Even Andrew Jackson at first rebuked the claim that the Kentucky militia had won him the campaign, even going so far as to refer to the militia as cowards in his diary by describing his militia in this manner: “Ingloriously fled from the scene of battle.”  Andrew Jackson & the Battle of New Orleans The Battle of New Orleans It was only while he was running for president that he decided to play along with the more “heroic” version of New Orleans by singing the song of the Kentucky militia repelling the entire British army.  The Battle of New Orleans Order of Battle and Scenario Rules Contrary to what some people have to say regarding the January 8, 1815 assault that witnessed 2,000 British soldiers falling within a matter of minutes, the true bloodiest battle of the war was the Battle of Lundy’s Lane, fought on July 25, 1814, and the number of casualties sustained on both sides was still far less than what the British are alleged to have suffered in a single assault. It is estimated that each side took roughly 800 dead, wounded or captured, with the Americans possibly suffering slightly higher casualties. Aside from the Battle of Chippawa, fought only a few weeks earlier — the only battle which the Americans won in the war without vastly outnumbering their enemy — Lundy’s Lane was the closest that the Americans came to winning a battle on Canadian soil.  Battle of Lundy's Lane | Marriott Niagara Falls Hotel Battle of Lundy's Lane - Wikipedia Americans who took part in the campaign involving the battles of Chippawa and Lundy’s Lane were regarded as “the best of the best” and were recruited from multiple armies and placed into a single army and trained off the front lines for the better part of the year in hopes of having an army at the European level of quality. By no means, did they represent the average American in terms of combat skill, as the American forces relied far more on quantity than quality until the final stages of the war when it was becoming imminent that a ceasefire was inevitable, due to the unwinnable war the American government had thrust itself into without gaining any notable achievements.  Winfield Scott: Defender of Irish Rights ... Once Battle of Chippawa - Wikipedia In previous battles, such as at Queenston Heights, Chateauguay, Frenchtown, Beaver’s Dam and Crysler’s Farm, American armies were vanquished, despite vastly outnumbering their opponents. For instance, there were fewer than 800 Canadians and British present at Crysler’s Farm; meanwhile, the Americans — numbering as many as 8,000 — were completely routed from the battlefield, halting the invasion of Canada for yet another season.  The Battle of Crysler’s Farm Battle of Crysler's Farm - Wikipedia The majority of artillery present during the New Orleans campaign were under the command of Jean Lafitte, a famous French pirate who was told by Andrew Jackson that he and his men would be compensated generously if they would agree to help out in the fight against the British.  Pirate Jean Lafitte Countered Governor's $500 Bounty for Him with a $5,000 Bounty for Governor Not credited for the defence regarding the New Orleans campaign were some Native Americans living in the south, who were also promised by Jackson that he would grant them their own homeland if they agreed to help him expel the British. While he was initially true to his word, Jackson would later turn on the very warriors who had fought for him, by purging them from their homes and exiling them in an incident now known as “The Trail of Tears.” Trail of Tears One of the main reasons why the assault on New Orleans itself never got underway, was because the British army that did engage the Americans under the command of Edward Pakenham were never assigned to the taking of the city.  The Sad Fate of Wellington’s Brother-in-Law That task was supposed to be left to the two northern armies, who received the message in time regarding the Treaty of Ghent, so they never partook in the campaign. Furthermore, disease withered down the British who did take part in the campaign, and it is estimated that no fewer than 1,000 of them died during these three weeks (more than three times the number killed in action), as the weather was also said to have been unusually grim, with rain and mud being a part of a soldier’s life during these harrowing weeks. By late 1814, the Americans were in such disarray, that they felt that the only adequate defence they could put up against the British was by placing their entire army in the south, as far away from the Canadian border as possible.  James Madison Biography: Fourth President of the United States Contrary to popular belief, the New Orleans campaign was also NOT the last engagement of the war. Because the Americans refused to honour the Treaty of Ghent after the British withdrew from the region (upon hearing of the news of the treaty) the surviving British of the New Orleans campaign continued to raid other American forts and settlements, including the capturing of Fort Bowyer, which is ubiquitously regarded as the last land battle of the war involving British and American soldiers (native Americans continued to fight amongst each other for several weeks afterwards).  On this day in Alabama history: Second Battle of Fort Bowyer began - Alabama NewsCenter It is very unlikely that the war would have ended in favour of the Americans had they decided to turn down the treaty offered, as James Madison himself was so desperate to ending the war that he told his diplomats to accept just about any condition, other than the annexation of the United States itself, as a condition for ending the war. The War of 1812 was also not a war that “unified” the Americans, but was in fact so unpopular and divisive that it is also regarded as the war that came closest to breaking the United States, with the possible exception of the American Civil War itself, half a century later. The controversy and disdain surrounding the war also outdid Vietnam, which actually saw far more favourable support from the American population than the War of 1812 did. Even though most American soldiers who saw action during the war were from the north, it was the northern states who were most opposed to it, and states such as Massachusetts outright refused to send their soldiers to war, even though William Hull — commander at the Siege of Detroit — was himself from Massachusetts.  16 August 1812 - Siege of Detroit - Also known as the Surrender of Detroit, or the Battle of Fort Detroit, was an early engagement in the Wa… | pre ww1 | Pinterest | War of 1812, Military history and American war It is, however, still worth noting that despite the discrepancy surrounding the number of citizens from northern states who took part in the war versus those from the south, it was the south that was generally more favourable to the war, while the north was less favourable. This line of division would play out almost the same in the American Civil War when those who had favoured the war in overwhelming numbers (the Confederacy) would be pitted against citizens from states that had not supported the war (the Union). All in all, I think that it is safe to conclude that the War of 1812 was a clear-cut American defeat: They failed to take Canada, even when they had more than sufficient manpower to do so (eight million Americans versus fewer than 300,000 Canadians at the time)And the Treaty of Ghent was largely decided while the war was on American soil, with James Madison being quite open to accepting any treaty in order to end the war as hastily as possible Arthur Wellesley, who would take part in the Waterloo campaign against Napoleon five months later, was himself personally offered the job of defeating the Americans in North America, along with his veteran army that had just concluded the Iberian Wars in Spain. Despite the fact that Wellesley was himself not too keen on going over to North America, it is very unlikely that he would have been able to turn down the offer if pressed to do so. Ultimately, he would never be compelled to make that decision to go, as the Americans eventually relented and agreed to uphold the terms of the Treaty of Ghent, despite initially declining to do so for a few weeks after the New Orleans campaign had ended.  Fort Niagara War of 1812 Encampment Even though the United States may have been able to keep Carleton Island as part of their prize, I still think that the fact that a population of fewer than 300,000 Canadians — more than half of whom were either first or second generation Americans — in an agricultural society were able to defeat a population of eight million Americans from an industrial society — even when their two best commanders, Isaac Brock and Tecumseh were killed early on — is quite a feat, even by today’s standards. The evidence and history speaks for itself. And the evidence is that the War of 1812 was an American defeat.

What do you call a war that includes a botched invasion of your enemy’s territory, your capital being burned while your government flees in the middle of the night, and accomplishment of none of your official war aims? Ladies and gentlemen, I give you the War of 1812.  Now, I know that (many) American schools don't teach it that way. We tell our kids that this was Revolutionary War: Part 2, where we go toe-to-toe with the mighty British Empire not as scrappy rebels, but as equals, and give them what-for. That this was the United States entering the world stage! Ridiculous. The war was at best a sideshow. For all of 1812 and 1813 and well into 1814, Britain had her hands full with this guy:  That's Napoleon, of course. While we were “proving ourselves” by sending a ragtag militia unit or two north to raid Canada and steal their maple syrup (or whatever) Britain could barely be bothered to notice what was happening halfway across the world. For two years, they had bigger fish to fry on the Continent. As soon as Napoleon had been defeated for good, the British troops showed up for real. Over a period of about three weeks in the summer of 1814, they proceeded to utterly crush our economy and burn city after city, basically unopposed. In particular, they sailed into the newly-constructed capital of Washington, DC and burned it, including the Treasury, Department of State, Department of War, both houses of Congress, and most famously, the Executive Mansion. Dolley Madison had the good sense to grab the painting of George Washington on her way out of the house to save it from the British troops (our actual president, James Madison, having left town the day before).  “Thanks for nothing, James.” Only a timely bit of rain saved the city itself from burning to the ground. They also basically robbed Alexandria blind in exchange for its surrender, and proceeded to shell Baltimore, our richest mid-Atlantic port, among other indignities. Fortunately we managed to withstand a few of these attacks, as well as a counter-invasion in northern New York, and the British didn't really want to fight yet another war anyway after half a century of on-and-off warfare against the French. So within a year everyone had signed a peace treaty that put everything back exactly as it was beforehand. “Mr Madison’s Little War” didn't even get the British to agree to stop pressing our sailors into their Navy, which was the whole reason we declared war in the first place. But with the defeat of Napoleon, they weren't as desperate for sailors anyway, so it all worked out, I guess. The biggest end result of the war, besides us painting the Executive Mansion white to hide the fire damage, was a nice poem about a flag. That was written by amateur poet Francis Scott Key as he watched the British shell Baltimore on their way back from looting D.C. He set his new poem to a catchy British pub song and a century later, it became our official national anthem: the Star-Spangled Banner. “But wait!” I hear you shouting. “"What about the Battle of New Orleans?!” Ah yes, we loooove to talk about the Battle of New Orleans, don't we? After all, it gave us a bona fide war hero who would later go on to be president: Andrew Jackson, who led the defense of the city against an overwhelming British force, and beat them back anyway.  “Keep fighting, men! Your deaths definitely matter.” Problem is, the battle happened after the treaty ending the war had been signed — nobody involved in the battle knew; news from Europe took a few weeks to arrive by boat in those days — so it meant literally nothing and accomplished literally nothing. If Jackson had surrendered, or been defeated, or been beamed up by aliens in the middle of the fight, the British would still have been forced to walk right back onto their ships and go home as soon as the news of the treaty arrived. (Also, Jackson was a terrible president, one of our worst, but that's an article for another day). So, yes. We took advantage of a distracted Britain to poke her in the side for two years, and then as soon as they had a free moment we got our asses handed to us, our cities burnt, our economy wrecked, our government run out of town, and one “hero” whose battle didn't even matter, and then everything went back exactly how it was. Also, a poem. We lost the War of 1812.

There are a bunch of answers I disagree with here. I am going to single out a passage from Brian Collins’s answer: “Might the governments of Afghanistan and Iraq fall to enemies of the US? Yeah, but it hasn’t happened yet. The US also withdrew from Iraq, not after taking tons of casualties, but after a few years where the country was the most stable it had been since 2003.” Someone, von Clausewitz maybe, said, “War is diplomacy, carried out with other means.” Unfortunately, Osama bin Laden, a weak opponent, with multiple vulnerabilities, had the USA figured out. All he had to do was get the USA to appear to attack a muslim nation. Osama bin Laden, prior to 9–11, was a very fringe character. Even though he used his own millions, and got tens or hundreds of millions of Saudi Riyals from some of the most conservative Saudi princes, he was having a great deal of trouble raising a secret army to attack the USA. He had taken his group to Sudan, spent a huge amount of money, built the pharmaceutical plant Clinton bombed. So how many men did he raise? One insider account I read said when Sudan kicked him out, to prevent another US attack, he took just 150 followers with him. That might seem like enough, for a start, more men than Fidel Castro started out with. But it wasn’t, because too many of them were illiterate, or monoglot, or too dogmatic, or just plain too unintelligent to sneak into a western country, like the 9–11 hijackers were able to do. The reason why Osama bin Laden had so much difficulty raising a secret army, even when the wider community of muslims, contains a significant fraction who looked down on the USA as decadent, is that this disdain for the USA fell far short of being enough for all but a very tiny fraction of them to agree to participate in a sneak attack. I am not a Muslim. I was not that knowledgeable about Islam, before I started to read about this stuff, but, in 2005, I set myself the task of reading every page from the transcripts from the Guantanamo captives annual status review hearings. I got to read the so-called “evidence” against them, for myself, and read their answers. You will read the phrase “Islam is a religion of Peace”, and you will read bitter denunciations. Well, which is it. One can read the same thing about Christianity, that it is a religion of Peace, “love your enemies”, St. Francis, Koom-by-ya… And yet Christians launched crusades, tortured people during the inquisition, etc. It seems that Islam, as interpreted by almost every muslim, except Osama bin Laden, his cronies, and a very tiny minority of like-minded kooks, that included some super-rich Saudi princes, believed that Islam barred launching first strike attacks. Many muslims believe that the use of force was justified if the other side attacked first. This meant Osama bin Laden could get a much larger fraction of the wider Muslim community to commit to fighting the USA, if he could make the USA attack a muslim country. By August 2001 Osama bin Laden had spent over a dozen years, and an enormous amount of money, and had raised maybe 1000 guys, most of them, frankly, losers, like Richard Reid, the failed shoe bomber. When Khalid Sheikh Mohammed brought him the plan to use airliners to crash into iconic American buildings, full of innocent American civilians, Osama bin Laden guessed he had his winning move. For him to win all he had to do was get the USA to go to war with Afghanistan. Once he had done that he thought there would be a massive change, and all kinds of USA haters would come out of the woodwork. They wouldn’t be engaged in a sneaky first-strike attack, which Islam bars, instead they would be helping to defend fellow muslims. So, what should Bush have done to Afghanistan, rather than invade? Give diplomacy a chance. What if, after a few months of diplomatic pressure Afghanistan’s Taliban rulers had coughed up Osama bin Laden, and his leadership cadre, and extradited them to America? America would not have actually attacked a muslim country, and anyone like Osama bin Laden, like Zarqawi, for instance, would face exactly the same problem OBL faced, only the very most extreme fringe, would sign up to a sneak attack. What most people don’t know is that the Taliban was full of factions. Most people don’t know that Muttawakil, the Taliban’s Foreign Minister heard rumors of the 9–11 attack, in July of 2001, and sent the USA a warning, which the Bush administration ignored. After 9–11 Bush gave the Taliban a warning, to cough up OBL, but then only waited a few weeks, or a month, before attacking Afghanistan. That wasn’t nearly long enough. Muttawakil, the Foreign Minister, argued with his colleagues that they should turn over Osama bin Laden. It is a tragedy the USA resorted to force. When I see Americans crowing because, a decade later, they “got” Osama, I am disappointed all over again. He had already won. He had acheived his goal of turning attacking America from a prohibited sneaky sneak-attack, to an allowable defense of fellow muslims. Thanks alot Bush and Cheney. And what about Iraq? Remember the justification for the war? Prevent Saddam from launching a sneaky first-strike attack that used his vast and ready arsenal of A-bombs, nerve gas, and germ-warfare munitions. Remember what was found? Saddam didn’t have any WMD. He had meekly destroyed all his WMD, after his defeat in 1991, just as he was ordered to. Yes, he said he had destroyed them. Yes, he was a liar. But he wasn’t lying to the USA and UN inspectors. His lie was to his enemies, dissident elements in Iraq, and his immediate neighbors, like Iran. Keeping his unstable Sunni fraction in power required his enemies, internal and external, to have doubts, and suspect he had fooled the inspectors, and had hidden WMD, somewhere, he could use if the dissidents, or angry neighbors, attacked him. Bush and company had to move quickly, which is why they invented all those terrible, incredible lies. “Yellow cake Uranium”, the bizarre claim Saddam trained al-Qaeda fighters to use his WMD, the mobile labs, aluminum tubes. It was all crap. After the invasion apologists, like Collins, retreat to Iraq is in better shape than it was under Saddam. Bzzzt. Sure, Saddam was a brutal guy. His security forces used torture, to keep the population in order, and maybe even for fun. But this level of routine violence was dwarfed by the death toll of the invasion, and worse, the occupation. When the US had rolled over Saddam’s forces the Bush administration appointed this guy Bremer, to govern Iraq, with, essentially vice-regal power. Bremer got to spend $19 billion dollars the United Nations had been administering, under the Oil for Food program. And Bremer blew those funds, like a drunken sailor. Iraq’s water plants, for drinking water, and sewage treatment, had largely been destroyed in the war. Big US firm Bechtel got the contract to repair all the plants, for $2 billion. Yes, billions with a B. Bechtel made some efforts, but, in the end, did not repair a single water plant. However, that sweet-heart deal Bremer signed with them, let them keep the $2 billion anyway. If a huge number of Iraqi kids get cholera, are painfully sick and dying for a week or so, and then actually die, under the most painful circumstances, and that was all the fault of the USA, isn’t that worse than Saddam’s torturers killing dozens, maybe hundreds, of dissidents. When Saddam’s Iraqi torturers brutally and painfully murder other Iraqis, it is an internal Iraqi matter. But when the USA is responsible? Colin Powell called it the Pottery Barn rule, you broke it, you own it. Personally, it seemed to me the Bush-Cheney team rushed to invade Iraq before the international inspectors definitive report made clear he had no WMD, because, they feared, his regime would then collapse, and they would never have an excuse to invade. So, no, I will not agree that Iraq should not be classified as a defeat.

Of course, many times. Some have argued that there has to be a military defeat to “lose” a war. That is poppycock and completely misunderstands the nature and purpose of warfare. Military operations are only one narrow aspect of warfare, which has been described as “politics by other means.” In fact, wars are sometimes won and lost without combat at all. The Cold War is an example. That was our only existential war since WWII. As the USSR disolved along with its global empire of satelite states and alliances, they lost, we won, even though we never directly engaged in declared combat. One needn’t suffer a military defeat to lose a war. We spent years, billions, and tens of thousands of American lives in Vietnam and failed in our goals. That is a loss, however one wants to dress it up. Likewise, we have so far not won our war in Afghanistan. Since we haven’t left, one might argue that we haven’t lost yet. However, given what we have spent in blood and fortune, and how much we have discarded our objectives, I think that is not a strong arguement. We “won” the initial phase of the war in Iraq, the phase of major military objectives. We overthrew Sadaam Husein. Most of our other objectives though, establishing democracy, free markets, political stability, a geopolitical ally, even hearts and minds, was largely a big loss. We are still at war with North Korea over sixty years later. That one is more of a mixed bag, given the political and economic success of South Korea and our establishment of such a strong military presence in the region. But if North Korea succeeds in building an ICBM and nuclear payload that can reach the US, it is hard not to see that war as a major loss. Sometimes to win a war (or lose) all that has to happen is for the clock to run out. So yes, the US has lost many wars. In general we still like to dress them up as wins, or at least “not lost.” Not a very realistic or helpful assessment though, and the rest of the world has little trouble recognizing our losses.

It’s impossible to list every single conflict the US has been involved in, so I will limit this to the main wars. TLDR: I listed 14 wars. 10 wins. 1 civil war. 1 controversial(1812). 1 loss(Vietnam). 1 uncertain(Afghanistan). Basically 10–1 with a couple grey areas. An interesting note: the only war that can be definitively stated as a military defeat would be the War of 1812. Every other war the US either outright won or had a good mix of wins and losses. Revolutionary War(1775–1783) USA(with help from European countries, notably France) vs Britain and Indians - a clear-cut political victory, even though the USA lost a great many battles. I would say militarily it was mixed at best.War of 1812(1812–1815) USA vs Britain and Indians - one of the strangest wars in US history. Very few casualties on both sides. There is actually a lot of confusion as to what the goals were for the US, which is why you will have people on both sides declaring victory. My assessment is that this war was mostly a loss for the US militarily, as they lost most battles, but a political victory, as they gained grudging recognition from the Brits as an independent country, along with access to vast quantities of Indian land previously under the control of the British.Mexican-American War(1846–1848) USA vs Mexico - victory for the USA, both militarily and politically.Civil War(1861–1865) USA vs CSA - given that the USA never recognized the Confederate States of America as a legitimate country, this battle is technically between citizens of the same country. Thus “victory” in the context of this question is irrelevant.Spanish-American War(1898) - USA vs Spain - victory for the USA, both militarily and politically.Indian Wars(1600s-early 1900s) - USA and European countries vs Indian Tribes - this is one of the most controversial wars in US history, and has invoked a lot of accusations and claims by both sides. This was not one single conflict, but thousands of individual conflicts featuring different Indian tribes and different groups of US and European people. The conflicts started long before the US became a country, but the wars were continued after the US was formed. I will avoid making any type of comments on this, I will just say that clearly the USA won this war both militarily and politically.World War 1(1914–1918)(USA only fought 1917–1918) - USA and European allies vs European enemies - a lot of claims are made about the effect of US involvement in WW1, ranging from no effect to being the decisive point in the war. I will simply say that the US involvement certainly helped. As to how decisive, I will bow out of this one. Politically and militarily a win for the USA.World War 2(1939ish-1945)(USA only fought 1941–1945) - USA(and allies) vs Germany, Italy and Japan - this is also debated as to whether the US “won” the war. The best explanation I have found declares it this way. The war was won with British guts, Russian blood and American industry. Each member(including our other allies) were essential to winning the war. Without any one of these 3, winning would have been immeasurably more difficult, if not impossible. Politically and militarily a win for the USA.Cold War(1947–1991) - USA vs Soviet Union - no battles between the two, but proxy wars fought in Cuba, Korea, Vietnam, and others. Political win for the USA.Korean War(1950–1953) - USA(and allies) vs North Korea(and allies) - while technically this war is still going on, South Korea was liberated and the unofficial war ended in 1953. Tensions are still high, but at this point, it is certainly a political and military win for the USA.Vietnam War(1955–1975)(most fighting from 1963–1969) - USA(and allies) vs the North Vietnamese(and allies) - an overwhelming military victory for the USA, but a political loss.Persian Gulf War(1990–1991) - USA(and allies) vs Iraq - an overwhelming military and political victory for the USA.Iraq War(2003-???) - USA(and allies) vs Iraq - I’m not sure if this is still categorized as still going on, as the results of this war continue to this day. Militarily this is an obvious US win, and politically too, as the US forced the Iraqis to sue for peace. However, this is a very controversial war in the USA(and abroad), and this war has not helped the USA’s image internationally. Still a victory, but with an asterisk.Afghanistan(2001-present) - USA(and allies) vs Taliban - another controversial war that is still going on. Militarily the US has certainly got the better of the Taliban, but it has been quite clear for a number of years that this war cannot end in US political victory. I think that is why you have seen Trump begin negotiations with the Taliban on multiple occasions. Hopefully he(or the next President) is able to get us out of there, or at least negotiation some sort of agreement where the vast majority of the fighting stops. Military win, but political loss(or mixed).

On January 8, 1964, President Lyndon Johnson announced his “War on Poverty,” just one more of the “wars” lost by the United States. 50 years later, poverty still exists, despite the U.S. government having spent trillions of tax dollars to combat it. Far from being an invincible superpower, the United States has actually lost many wars, and here we list 10 of them. Depending on your politics and opinions, you may not agree with all of them. Please feel free to chime in with your thoughts about these “wars” and on any others you feel the U.S. is also losing. Digging Deeper 10. War on Poverty. With the U.S. poverty rate at 17% when the initiatives introduced by Johnson were instituted, the years since have seen the poverty rate sink as low as 11% but then climb as high as 15%, staying between those percentages ever since. Today 47% of taxpayers do not even earn enough to have to pay income tax, and the gap between rich and poor is greater than any other time in the nation’s history. The groups that benefited the most from Johnson’s programs (Medicare and Medicaid especially) were the elderly and those under 18 years old, while the poverty rate among those ages 18-64 years has basically remained the same. At an investment of $15 trillion, the return has been low and the achievements modest. For the very little gain, it has been catastrophic to the national budget. Over 46 million Americans remain in poverty, the highest number in U.S. history. 9. War on Drugs. The “War on Drugs” continues today despite every indication that this campaign is not a winning one. The U.S. appears to be powerless to stop the influx of cocaine, heroin and marijuana from outside the country, while almost every city and suburb has residential “chemists” making ecstasy, LSD and crystal meth in their basement laboratories. 8. War on Terror. Meanwhile, the U.S. has been fighting a “War on Terror” since 2001, but at what cost? Iraq and Afghanistan are more filled with terrorists and are more unstable than when initially invaded. Trillions of dollars have been squandered, not to mention the thousands of dead, crippled or psychologically scarred military personnel and civilian contractors. It is not surprising that the U.S. military is currently experiencing the highest suicide rate in its history. 7. War in Viet Nam. Of course by now most Americans realize the Viet Nam War was lost. The fact that the North overwhelmed the South and imposed their brand of communism on the whole country is proof. It is true that the U.S. military performed quite well and killed many more soldiers of the North Vietnamese Armey (NVA) and the Viet Cong (VC) than they themselves lost (perhaps a million or two Vietnamese for the loss of less than 70,000 Americans), but in the end, the war cannot be classified as a success. 6. War of 1812. Many scholars consider the War of 1812 a war lost by the U.S., with British troops burning the capitol among other cities such as Buffalo, New York. While the U.S. did manage to win the last battle of the war, American forces failed to take any part of Canada, and the grievances that precipitated the war had largely already been resolved before any hostilities started. 5. The Cold War. One has to ask, did the U.S. really win the Cold War? Or, were there no real winners? Spending incredible sums on weapons and “intelligence” certainly has kept the U.S. from progressing and its citizens from enjoying anywhere near the standard of living they could be. Sure, the Soviet Union broke up under the weight of its expenses, but what did the U.S. gain? Despite the United States’ status as the only “superpower” left standing, not much else was gained, except perhaps for some defense contractors being richer. 4. War on Christmas. Some people today would say the U.S. or perhaps the world for that matter, is also conducting a “War on Christmas,” an effort by secular or atheistic people who want to eliminate Nativity scenes from public places and replace “Merry Christmas” with “Happy Holidays.” Alternatives offered include Kwanzaa and Festivus (“for the rest of us”) or maybe a return to acknowledging the winter solstice. With the amount of decorations, sales, marketing, parades and flood of television specials, Christmas is still winning this war. 3. War on Women. Democrats and other liberals are fond of saying that the Republicans and conservatives are conducting a war on women. This war is being fought through the opposition of equal pay for equal work statutes, the limitation or prohibition of abortion and no government subsidization of contraceptives. Of course, the right wing claims they are conducting no such war, but if they were, they would certainly be losing it because women are in positions of power like never before. 2. War on Unions/Middle Class. Like the so-called “War on Women,” the war against working-class people is allegedly being fought between the right and left political factions in American politics. “Right to work” and similar laws that gut unions as well as idiotic tax codes that make moving manufacturing out of the country profitable are killing the American worker and destroying the “middle class dream.” Furthermore, convoluted income tax laws end up costing successful workers a higher percentage of their income in taxes than filthy rich people have to pay on income made through capital gains investments. Disappearing medical benefits, vacations holidays, and the rolling back of laws that mandate time-and-a-half pay for overtime are some of the results of this conflict. We would not say the American worker is defeated, but things are not going very well for the working and middle class. 1. War on Crime. Although violent crimes such as murder and car theft occur less often than they used to, the average American is under the impression the country is some sort of fire-free zone. Police are exhorted by politicians to be active and “produce” (tickets and arrests) but are then thrown under the bus when the public cries that they are are bullying them with “stop and frisk,” “broken windows,” and DUI checkpoints. In addition, there are an incredible amount of abuses of corporate power that oftentimes nearly ruin the country, and, unlike the poor man who writes a bad check, none of the big bankers or investors go to jail. Statistics may make it seem that the good guys are making progress, but it just does not feel like it.

Officially, no. At no point has the US been forced to surrender to another nation. There are only two disputable wars that most people bring up. War of 1812 - The US officially declared a draw with Britain. Although the White House was burned, the US obliterated Britain in New Orleans. The US and Britain eventually agreed to end the conflict rather evenly.Vietnam - The US spent over a decade pounding North Vietnam and her allies into the dirt. Although it came at the cost of 50,000+ plus American Soldiers, the North Vietnamese lost far more militarily as you would expect. However, the US never actually surrendered. By 1973 the US withdrew from Vietnam, leaving the country of South Vietnam to continue on its own. Although North Vietnam would soon defeat South Vietnam, the US withdraw wasn’t a surrender.Militarily the US never lost a war. However, whether they strategically lost any conflict is another matter. In that situation you’d need to analyze what the US goals were as compared to their enemies goals and then compare to see who accomplished what. Under this analysis, you can make a good argument that the US never won in Vietnam, to which I’d agree. However, upon just viewing the military side of the conflict, the US has never lost a war. Edit: Some have gotten rather testy about me asserting that US didn’t lose Vietnam, and have sent me messages because of this. Let me explain why I stand by this statement. The US never lost a major battle in Vietnam. For over a decade we pummeled the North Vietnamese, inflicting a combined total of over a 1 million losses over the course of the war. In 1973 the US brokered the Paris Peace Accords, which was a peace treaty ending the war and establishing both North and South Vietnam as separate governments. The US proceeded to end its military involvement in the region, similar to what happened in South Korea. However, the US also ended any commitment to defense and funding. After 2 years North Vietnam proceeded to break the peace treaty and invade South Vietnam. Without American financial support, the South quickly folded. Since the US military was not present after 1973, having voluntarily withdrawn and left South Vietnam to continue the fight, it is impossible to assert that the US was militarily defeated.

This question isn’t very easy to answer. ‘War’ is a rather subjective term when used in a non-legal context. In US law, Congress votes to declare war, while the President actively commands the military conflict and has powers to deploy US forces. Nowhere in the US Constitution though, does it say Congress formally declaring war is the only way to have a war. Out of the times the US actually declared war, the only time the US arguably did not come out on top was in the War of 1812. The court decisions (or decisions to ignore even hearing) Doe v. Bush and Massachusetts v. Laird, imply that simply authorising military force is enough for the President to send in the military to engage in a military conflict. The US has been in undeclared wars since 1794. It’s not like you can even convincingly argue ‘the Founding Fathers never intended!’ because the Founding Fathers themselves authorised military force in the Quasi-War without declaring war. Out of undeclared wars, it is still easy to argue either way without conducting significant mental gymnastics. I think out of undeclared wars, everyone would agree, for example, that the US beat Panama because at the end of the day, the Panamanian government fell, US troops won every engagement, and the former dictator of Panama was in a US prison until 2007. For Vietnam however, the situation is much more complicated. I mean here are some ways you can argue: Yes the US lost: The US failed to prop up South Vietnam.The US withdrew, and South Vietnam was toppled by North Vietnam.The US achieved absolutely none of its political objectives from the war. It failed to contain communism in Southeast Asia. In war, the results can be called outright victory, Pyrrhic Victory, a draw resulting in a cease-fire or truce, or even a treaty of peace or cessation of hostilities, or a loss. A loss can be categorized in a few ways: loss of the military and/or political goals of the war in the face of the enrmy’s response; loss of an irreplaceable number of men or war equipment such that fighting cannot continue; total defeat on the battlefield followed by or solely due to, invasion and occupation by the enemy concurrent with the surrender of one’s sovereignty to the enemy. As military loss alone is defined, the US has lost many battles, but never one time has she lost any war. As military/political loss is defined, the US has never one time surrendered to any enemy, nor sued for peace to end any war from the position of military weakness. The US has never “lost” a war. Losing a war is catastrophic. Even negotiating a peace from the position of military insufficiency (the inability to win the war) can be socio-economically devastating as in the 1919 Treaty of Versailles’ crushing sanctions on Germany. The War of 1812 is probably the closest thing to a loss in battle of a war the US has ever had. The result was best described as a truce, neither side so clearly in command on the battlefield as to dictate terms. Many know that the Battle of New Orleans, the US’ most lopsided victory in that war, happened after the Treaty of Ghent had already been signed. This for some reason seems to lessen the battle’s ferocity to many. But the combatants did not know the war was over. The fight was very real, desparate, bloody, and despite being outnumbered 3-to-1, Jackson’s Americans routed Cochrane and Pakenham’s larger British force. Many know that, but most don’t know that the war began when the US declared war of the UK in response to the English blocade of France, America’s chief Revolutionary War ally. Or that the US invaded Canada as part of the UK. Or that British troops in Canada and native Canadian colonials repelled the American invasion. The war ended status quo ante bellum, meaning ‘the way things were before the war’: nobody won but nobody lost. Korea was a cease-fire. Still. Militarily, MacArthur was on fire, but politically, he was trouble, and Truman and the rest of the UN didn’t want to fight China to the death over Koryo. So the UN withdrew to an agreed-upon line, and fences were built and gun emplacements and radars, and the Mini Cold War goes on. Vietnam was not a loss. Vietnam was a we quit. We shouldn’t have been there, our involvement was manufactured, our politicians were not behind the war effort; one President micromanaged the war sometimes to Company level, another wavered on his committment to ending the war and in the middle of it went all stupid and embroiled the country in its worst political scandal; the country was ripping itself apart on a very large scale over an unnecessary, unjust, hated war, and finally, everybody just said stop. In Vietnam, we quit a war we never should have started. We can debate the Sand Box Wars’ values, but militarily, it is clear that America-led Allies cannot be beaten by the enemy. Their only victories are political and propaganda. Again, America just quit most of its involvement. Just packed up and left after telling the enemy the date, and now because all the enemy did was hide and wait, we’re sending more Americans back in because either the job wasn’t finished or because we should believe that the same bowl of alphabet soup with new letters floating on top but the same cast of characters in the broth represents a new threat to the US. What is the only war the US ever lost? If I’m alive when it happens, we won’t need to ask or answer.

Contrary to other answers: Officially, yes. The united states has lost 8 wars since the american revolution, the first of which being Red cloud’s war [1866–1868], where the United states were in battle against various native american tribes. This battle ended with land given to the natives. During this time, in 1867 america lost the Formosa expedition, a short war where the Americans retreated after a single casualty. The United states were also involved in the Russian civil war in 1918–1920. The allied powers had to retreat, ending in a communist victory. The U.S. also lost another civil war, the Laotian civil war from 1953–1975, where the U.S. was defeated and Lao people’s democratic republic was established. The U.S. lost the Bay of pigs invasions against Cuba in 1961. The most notable defeat was the Vietnam war, taking place from 1965–1973 and a quick uprising in 1975. Where the U.S., South Vietnam and a few other countries lost to North Vietnam, the soviet union, north Korea and a few other countries. The U.S. lost the Cambodian civil war in 1967–1975, with the fall of the Kingdom of Cambodia. The United states’ most recent loss was from 1982–1984, during the Lebanese civil war. Just to be clear, the United states did not lose the war of 1812. The United states just suffered great losses. To note these are documented losses. They are conflicts where the U.S. had retreated [not through force of the other nation] or unoccupied the space of war. The U.S. has never surrendered, but these are defeats in which the United states retracted their forces.

The United states is not really old enough to have participated in many wars, and wars that are considered to be ‘won’ by countries are mostly either classical or semi classical warfare before the advent of self loading or breach loading firearms. The last real single country on single country big power vs big power wars which involved capitulation of either party really has to be the Napoleonic wars, or even back further such as England VS Scotland, the forging of the various European continental empires such as the Austro-Hungarians/Byzantines/Ottomans. These large scale expeditionary conquests which involved the forging of nations are all before the time of the US- a product of colonialism with a very short (just over 200 year old) history. The big point here is the US was formed in the gunpowder age, and has never known bladed conflict with classical formations. It also was very very young during the industrial revolution and most of its history is one of mechanical/industrial growth. Just like the child who can play with an Iphone at 6; you give a young nation gunpowder and industry it is going to be better at using them than its ‘parents’ because they are still living on long lost memories- The British, for example still use two fingers as a swearword to commemorate a victory 600 years old, 3 times older than the US! In this modern age warfare is usually fought in alliances and gone are the days of absolute raping/burning/capitulation and humiliation of a nation (with WWII having been an exception, but it could be argued that WWII was really a battle between the ‘parents’ with a complicated history of hundreds of years of previous wars, ethnic tensions, kingdoms and hangovers from the Napoleonic era that America could not have possibly understood the concept of as a young nation) and most modern wars are really skirmishes and involve allies in complicated, non historical or ethnic contexts- there was no historical reason Australia and the US should deal with France and defend Vietnam, for example. So the US, as a standalone nation has not had any definitive ‘wins’ or ‘looses’. But none of the other big power countries have any stand alone wins since before the creation of the United States, either. I guess we should all be thankful that most of us are far removed from the days of total war and not really worry so much about chalking up the score. There is no real winners in a war anyway.

Kind of the inverse to the question has the US ever won a war. I should think the answer is yes. Regardless of what right wing nuts say, Vietnam was a clear loss. Korea certainly wasn’t a win and considering consequences we are experiencing today, it is looking more loss than win. I certainly would call Afghanistan a win. The war is 16 years old this year. I can’t see the Iraq incursion a win either and we are still mired down in that mess. None of these losses or non-wins can be laid entirely on the military. Wars the US doesn’t win is largely owing to unrealistic political objectives and ignorance of the axiomatic ‘never start a ground war in Asia.’ I suppose defining won/loss should be decided on achievement of objectives. None of the above wars ever had clearly defined goals that remained constant. In World War II, all of the Allies agreed not to establish independent peace with Axis powers and to fight for unconditional surrender of the enemy. Was the goal of the Korean War re-establishing the border between North and South Korea? Or was it the reunification of Korea? I think MacArthur believed the latter while Truman had other ideas. Eisenhower wanted the conflict resolved one way or another. The goals in Vietnam were so confusing 42 years after the conquest of Saigon by the North I remain unclear why we were in Vietnam in the first place. The ‘Domino Effect’ was rubbish in 1965 when we consider that Ho Chi Mein was our guy in Indochina from 1941–1946 receiving funding and weapons through OSS. We screwed the Viet Mihn by dropping support for Ho and supporting French efforts at re-colonization. The 1975 Paris accords between the US and North Vietnam were largely identical to the 1955 accords between France and North Vietnam. If the US had not let bin Laden and company escape at Tora Bora in December 2001, that would have pretty much ended al Qaeda and the US could have left Afghanistan to the Taliban. Considering how crazy they are maybe that wouldn’t have been such a good idea. Still, defined strategic objectives would have been helpful. The Iraq conflict was completely unjustified although getting rid of the Iraqi Ba'athist certainly wasn’t a bad idea the entire affair was completely mismanaged and merely made rich Americans a lot more richer—crony capitalism in its ‘finest’ hour. I should mention the Philippines-American War 1899–1902. This was very ugly and brutal. It’s unclear to me what McKinley’s goals were when the war began. In 1900, Roosevelt and Taft began what was called ‘the policy of attraction,’ which by 1902 had managed to win many Filipino adherents. In 1916 the Jones Act guaranteed Philippines independence but a large degree of home rule had already been established with the first elected assembly in 1907. Since the US never actually established a clear strategic objective it’s hard to call the results a win or a loss. I think this might best be decided by the Filipino people. It’s quite possible that if a US presence had not been established in 1899 the Japanese might have moved in long before 1941. Again, Filipinos should decide whether Japanese or American colonialism was preferable. I honestly don’t know how contemporary Filipino people feel about this. I suspect US backing of the ludicrously corrupt Marcos regime from 1965–1986 has likely tainted Filipino views of pre-war American governance. Marcos was one of Reagan’s autocratic non-communists; hence Marcos victims were largely ignored. Had Marcos been a socialist I have to believe he never would have survived 21 years, ending his days a rich man living in Hawaii.

Even though the United States has never lost any territory or surrendered to another country, yes. Starting from the beginning (going by Wikipedia’s list of wars involving the USA) the Quasi-War was fought between the US and the French from 1798 to 1800. The US refused to pay France debts they owed from the American Revolutionary War because the French monarchy toppled during the French Revolutionary Wars, so the debts were owed to a regime that no longer existed. In response, France dusted off their best suits, knocked on America’s door, and started sending privateers to capture American ships en route to England and sell them as prizes. In July 1797, US diplomats Charles Cotesworth Pinckney, John Marshall, and Elbridge Gerry arrived in Paris and soon after met with men representing Foreign Minister Talleyrand, demanding things such as a large loan to the French government and a £50,000 bribe to Talleyrand. It became known as the XYZ affair. Congress authorized the gussying up of the navy, and on July 7, 1798 they rescinded all treaties with France and authorized the attack on French warships two days later. What followed was a two year war fought entirely at sea. The US only lost one ship which was later recaptured—the USS Retaliation, which was actually a captured French privateer La Croyable. Hostilities eventually died down after some bickering in the West Indies and Atlantic Ocean, and the Convention of 1800 officially signaled the end of the war. The problem is, war was technically never declared. The result of the Quasi-War is officially indecisive. Fast forward twelve years, and the United States and Britain were fighting again. This time it was for a variety of reasons: Britain introduced trade restrictions on France due to a minor disagreement called the Napoleonic Wars, so the US declared it illegal under international law. Britain also was allied with a few Native American tribes who lived in what was then the Northwest Territories and now Michigan, Wisconsin, Indiana, Illinois and Ohio. Britain’s goal was to create a “neutral” Native American state there, while America’s goal was—surprise!—expansionism. So we rolled up our sleeves, and America came, saw, and…kind of left after your standard wartime fun. Neither side gained or lost territory, and the war officially ended in a draw. Depending on who you ask some say that the war ended in an American win because of the victories at Baltimore, Plattsburgh and New Orleans, but some also say that it the British won because they technically achieved their goal—stopping repeated American invasions of Canada) and retaining their colonies. The Utah War (1857–1858) ended in resolution through negotiation, giving full amnesty to those convicted of sedition and treason and replacing Brigham Young as governor, and the Second Samoan War (1898–1899) ended in compromise with the Tripartite Convention, breaking up the Samoan Islands into a German colony and the US territory. The only times we’ve explicitly lost wars were the Red Cloud’s War and US interventions in the Russian, Lebanese and Somali Civil Wars. (Wikipedia includes the Bay of Pigs Invasion since we failed to assassinate Castro as well, and the Formosa Expedition is also considered this because we withdrew.) Red Cloud’s War ended with the Treaty of Fort Laramie after the Fetterman Massacre that killed 81 soldiers, a captain and the namesake, (also a) captain William J. Fetterman, followed by the realization that we didn’t have enough manpower. There were divided objectives amongst the other countries that comprised of the allies during the Russian Civil War and lack of domestic support, leading to near-total withdrawal in 1920 (a couple of Japanese forces decided to hang out for a few years after) and Bolshevik (pro-Communist) victory over the White Movement. Multinational forces failed to prevent the collapse of the Lebanese Army, and they evacuated after the Islamic Jihad Organization bombed the US embassy and marine barracks. The war continued until 1990 and Syrian occupation ended in 2005. Somali National Alliance leader Mohamed Farrah Aidid wasn’t captured (although he was killed after about a year of serving as president), we withdrew our forces after the loss at the Battle of Mogadishu, and the civil war’s still ongoing. I’m not exactly sure if I should include the Vietnam War since I know it’s a hot button topic, but seeing that we withdrew and North Vietnam took over South Vietnam, leading to a communist government being implemented in the entire country as well as Laos and Combodia, I don’t think it’d be far-fetched to call it a failure as well.

Since the country's formation following the American Revolutionary Era, the United States has been regarded by most of the outside world as a military power to be reckoned with. However, there have been some U.S.-involved conflicts where American success has not always been the rule of the day. War of 1812 The War of 1812 lasted for two years between 1812 and 1814. It saw a series of battles between the United States and Great Britain over the issue of British violations of U.S. maritime rights. As a British colony, Canada also played an important role in the war by fighting on behalf of the British. Though the United States did not win the war in a clear-cut manner, the Treaty of Ghent was signed on December 24, 1814, restoring relations between the two warring factions. It also restored the boundaries of the United States and colonial Britain to pre-war conditions. Much of the U.S. capital of Washington, D.C. was burnt by the British during the conflict, and the young nation was shaken to its core. Nonetheless, numerous American war heroes emerged from the fighting (such as Andrew Jackson for his involvement at the Battle of New Orleans and the fight against Creeks in Alabama and Georgia). The national anthem of the United States was also inspired by the hostilities, as Francis Scott Key was inspired to pen the lyrics of "The Star-Spangled Banner" as he witnessed the Battle of Fort McHenry in the harbor of Baltimore, Maryland in September of 1814. Powder River Indian War The Battle of Powder River was fought on March 17th, 1876 in what is now the U.S. state of Montana. The event witnessed an embarrassing defeat for the United States, when a poorly planned attack on a Cheyenne encampment by Colonel Joseph J. Reynolds resulted in significant losses suffered by the United States at the hands of Native Americans. Though Colonel Reynolds managed to damage a sufficient amount of Native property, the Natives who fought bravely gained confidence from the warfare, and were able to consolidate their powers to resist the demands of the United States in the future years. After the war, Colonel Reynolds was highly criticized for his misguided tactics, including for leaving several U.S. soldiers on the battlefield in the face of enemy fire, and for losing a large number of horses. He was initially suspended from duty for a year, and ultimately never returned to service again. This battle occurred almost 11 years after the Powder River Expedition, wherein the United States' Federal forces fought against Cheyenne, Arapaho, and Sioux in what are now the present-day U.S. states of Montana, Nebraska, Wyoming, and South Dakota. This earlier expedition also ended without serving the U.S. Federal interest of securing a dominating presence and securing peace in the region. Red Cloud's War The United States lost another war to Native American forces in the Red Cloud’s War. Waged between 1866 and 1868, this conflict was fought over control of parts of the Powder River area of what is now Wyoming, between the Bighorn Mountains and Black Hills. The war was fought between the Lakota Sioux, Northern Arapaho, and Northern Cheyenne as allies on one side, and the United States on the other. At the end of the war, the victorious Lakota managed to retain legal control over the Powder River Country, as per the Treaty of Fort Laramie, which was signed on April 29th, 1868. The Lakota were guaranteed ownership of the Black Hills, and maintained their land and hunting rights in the region. However, this victory lasted for only 8 years. Then, with the end of the Great Sioux War, the Powder River Country was ultimately captured by the U.S. forces. Formosa Expedition (Paiwan War) Considered to be one of the greatest failures of the U.S. Navy, the Formosa Expedition (or the Paiwan War) of 1867 witnessed the retreat of U.S. forces before the U.S. target of defeating the Paiwan natives was achieved. The battle was triggered when Taiwanese Aborigines killed the Ame. Follow me for more such content Onkar Pawar Thank you!!!

Some good answers here, but I would also add another, the War of 1812. Of course it all depends on how you measure “win” and “lose”. But look at it this way. America launched the war hoping for at least three positive outcomes. Firstly (the public pretext) to stop the Royal Navy taking British seamen out of American ships they had run to so as to avoid the Royal Navy press gangs. Secondly, the war hawks faction wanted to take possession of Canada. Thirdly, they wanted to prevent the British in Canada encouraging the Native Americans making trouble on the frontier. At the end of the war, they had basically achieved none of these. The Royal Navy carried on pressing runaways as before (though they mostly stopped simply because the war with France was over and they no longer needed the men). The Canadians beat off the American invasions, and while the Native Americans were heavily defeated and lost some important personalities, it was doubtful whether the British had really needed to agitate them, since the behaviour of some American frontier settlers was doing that quite adequately. Yes, the Americans won a few significant battles (New Orleans most notably even if late), and they took territory from the Spanish (which was never the original plan), their actual war aims all came to nothing. In the process, the US economy was trashed, Washington DC was largely burned down (in retaliation for US abuses in Canada), and of course the needless loss of life. Out of that war, America gained a national anthem, and a sense of nationhood that they didn’t really have before. Not bad things in themselves, but amplified with legends to cover over just how embarrassing the war was. The British can hardly call it a win either of course. The only country that can definitely claim it as a win is Canada.

You could list many, but historians and politicians can never agree on whether or  not we actually "lost" the war in question. For example: The Vietnam War took years to fight, yet after troves of failed strategies and an unbudging communist threat still looming from the North the US withdrew leaving a small and undersupplied South Vietnamese army to fend for itself, and ultimately, succumb to defeat . So, as one school of thought would proclaim, "you can't lose a war if you weren't there to lose it"  South Vietnamese residents being denied transportation aboard US evacuation helicopters. Prior to Vietnam was the Korean War, the first real slugout between Capitalism and Communism in Southeast Asia. The war itself was, in essence a shoving match starting with a full North Korean invasion of the Southernmost peninsula. This outrageous offensive rattled heads in Washington who immediately lead a UN counteroffensive at inchon, continually pushing the North Korean forces back North until the fighting neared the Chinese border who, fearing the Koreans would be pushed to their border, launched a counter-counter invasion allying with the North Koreans and, in turn, pushed the joint US, South Korean, UN offensive back to the 38th Parallel where an armistace was signed, calling for a DMZ (Demilitarized Zone) at the 38 Parralel. The Armistace signaled the end of fighting but not an official end to the war. Today the DMZ remains one of the most high tension areas in the world with the US still actively assisting in its fortification.  A US Army Officer and two South Korean troops actively observe the South Korean Demilitarized Zone. While these wars were not technically lost, they bear all of the hallmarks of lost wars such as public outcry and economic troubles. These wars were gauged by destruction (the US caused a trmemndous amount), yet they were conceded as lost by politics. Image Sources: 1975. Nha Trang. By DAVID HINCKLEY, NEW YORK DAILY NEWS, "Last Days In Vietnam" Wikimedia Commons

The War of 1812 could be most kindly described as a draw but basically we lost it. Vietnam was pretty clearly a defeat, although people love to say we were not defeated in the field. Perhaps true, but definitely irrelevant. In terms of our war aims we flat out lost. Afghanistan has been an awful waste of life (ours and theirs) and money—we won in 2001, but the war didn’t end then, and we haven’t accomplished anything positive. Iraq (2003) was technically a victory. Iraq (2004–2011) was another matter. Our supposed aim, creating a stable, more or less secular pro-Western (or pro-U.S.) democracy was not achieved and once again the war was a tremendous waste of blood, treasure and good will. The damage done to Iraq was unconscionable. It should go down as one of the worst political decisions in our history, and one of the most avoidable. People ask why we don’t win our wars any more and the answer is pretty obvious. We put too much faith in what our military can do, ignore politics, and get into wars that have little or no relationship to our vital interests. Iraq was clearly flat out aggression. Afghanistan was probably technically legal, but it was a punitive expedition rather than a defensive war, and strategically stupid. Vietnam was again arguably defensible, but we approached it in too cavalier a manner and for internal political reasons. To put it in classical terms—we have focused on military power without making honest assessments of political reality. Again, lots of people will claim that these failures are due to the American public’s unwillingness to stay for the long term. This is true. It is also something that everyone has understood for years (before Vietnam, and long before Afghanistan and Iraq), so it is not an excuse for stupid decisions.

Militarily, we’re 10–1–1. Diplomacy-wise, the US won the Revolution, tied the War of 1812, won the Mexican War, won the Spanish-American War, lost World War 1, won World War 2, tied Korea, lost Vietnam, lost the Gulf War, lost Iraq, and is struggling to tie in Afghanistan.  Diplomatically, we’re 4–4–3. Some qualifications on my statements: The British Empire fought the Revolution with one hand tied behind its back.  It decided the American colonies were too much of  a hassle, and that India and its eastern possessions were easier to manage.World War 1 - the Treaty of Versailles was arguably the greatest diplomatic disaster of the 20th Century.  We are still dealing with the effects of it in the Middle East.Korea - Did we win the peace?  Or did we lose the peace?  Was our aim to overrun North Korea until late 1950 when the Chinese entered?  Can we honestly say we lost the peace when South Korea is an Asian powerhouse?Vietnam - There were 12 major battles in Vietnam, and the US Army won them all.

The answer here is to part's, technically yes we have lost a war, legally we have never lost a war. how can both be correct if they are completely different answers? There is no question that the United States lost in Vietnam and Korea ended as a draw. The war of 1812 our capital was razed but we won out because of the Napoleonic War was Britain's focus. But remember I also said that the US has never lost a war. War's of attrition are not meant to conquer, but to outlast the enemies resolve. So this explains the War of 1812 since it was a war to stop Britain from seizing American merchant vessels. Let's focus then on the Korean conflict and the Conflict in Vietnam. Notice I used the word conflict and not war. In order for the United States to be engaged in a war Congress, not the President, must authorize a declaration of war. However in order to assist an Ally or stabilize a region, the President may, under the War Powers Act, put US troops in combat for 90 day's before asking Congress to go to war. At this point Congress can either declare war or stop funding the campaigns. This is what happened in Korea and Vietnam. We aided our Allies and Congress refused to declare war, yet they continued to fund the campaigns.  This is were the Media came into play. Their argument was that it was a war regardless. If the President has surpassed his time and Congress won't stop the campaigns, yet American troops are dying, it is an illegal war. This was how they reported it and how the American public saw it. So legally the United States has never lost a war, in reality we know that's not entirely true.
