We’ve only had two wars in our history that were real existential threats: the Civil War and WWII - and we’re still here. We provided an assist in WWI but hardly spent as much blood and treasure as the other nations. Most of our other wars were medium-level conflicts. The Revolution, of course, was unique. The closest thing to a clear loss was the War of 1812, where our invasion of Canada was repulsed (as it was during the Revolution) and the Brits burned Washington. (Some friends. They burned Washington down in 1814, but where are they now that we really need them?) They also captured Detroit. We scored some nice wins at sea, but basically we kept our independence because Britain didn’t really think conquering us was viable. Also, we were a side show in the Napoleonic Wars. As Bruce Catton said, it started after everyone had agreed not to fight and ended after everyone had agreed to stop fighting. We got a song out of it, demilitarization of the Great Lakes, and a start on the world’s longest undefended border. All failures should be so successful. (I sometimes say I was present when the War of 1812 ended. I was on a trip in the Appalachians and we stopped at Natural Bridge, Va. On the trail is a saltpeter cave mined for making gunpowder during the War of 1812. A British member of the group asked what that was. After recovering from my astonishment, I realized that from the British perspective, we were an absolutely inconsequential bunch of skirmishes when they had their hands full with Napoleon. So I gave him the US version about stopping our ships at sea, whereupon he stood at attention and in his best formal British voice, said “Well. On behalf of her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and the British Admiralty, I most humbly apologize.” So that’s settled. Seriously, guys, rule Britannia! And God Save the Queen.) We can offer suggestions and aid but they’ll have to evolve it on their own.We can’t defeat insurgencies. Oh, yeah, we can if we’re willing to fight very dirty and spend decades. But slam, bam, thank you ma’am, like the American public wants? No.Unless there’s a clear viable alternative out there, regime change merely means taking out one bad guy and allowing worse ones to move into the vacuum. Why did the U.S. back so many repressive governments during the Cold War? Look at Yugoslavia, Libya, Syria, Iraq…..

Most of the obvious answers have been stated. I’ll just add a little, though, about the single most glaring, brazen example of America losing a war and spinning it as a victory, or at least a “draw.” That was the War of 1812. The popular mythology of 1812—as purveyed on something like the History Channel, say—would leave most Americans believing the whole business was a British attempt to invade and subjugate America that the plucky little republic was just lucky to survive. This is because most American t.v. documentaries about the war gloss awkwardly over the real meat of it: which was the American attempt to invade Canada. Dress it up however you like, this was an almost purely opportunistic attempt to advance “manifest destiny” by carving off a piece of the British Empire while they were perceived to be busy with Napoleon. It was an utter and disastrous failure and defeat in every way, point blank. America started this war, lost it, failed in all its objectives and was sent packing, and that is as absolutely clear-cut as it gets. What allows the claim of its being a “draw” to persist is that America suffered a counterattack by the justifiably infuriated British. This of course was the counter-attack that famously saw the White House burned, but the notion that Britain was otherwise about to reconquer America doesn’t hold water. The objective was to punish the incursion into Canada so it wasn’t repeated, and this, too, Britain was largely successful. New Orleans—now much bally-hooed as a watershed in American history, a decoration on the personal myth of Andrew Jackson and proof of the republic’s enduring grit and independence—was in fact largely a sideshow that took place after a peace treaty had already been concluded (word of the armistice hadn’t reached the commanders involved). It had some effect on the eventual terms concluded after the war but in no way did it make the whole business a “draw.” America has some dubious mythology in circulation about its various wars, but it’s that one that truly takes the cake.

In Vietnam, we failed to accomplish the objectives we set out to achieve. It is widely considered to have been an American defeat, and even Robert S. McNamara and Henry Kissinger have agreed that victory was beyond our reach. The Korean War ended in a stalemate. It wasn't a defeat but it wasn't a victory either. The division of Korea today stands as evidence of no conclusive victory by either side. The little known conflict known as Red Cloud’s War (1866–1868) was actually the United States’ first decisive military defeat. It is seldom regarded as such, but taken alone is was clearly a defeat for the United States military. The discovery of gold in Montana let to the establishment of the Bozeman Trail, running from Fort Laramie and heading through the traditional hunting grounds of the Lakota, Northern Cheyenne, and Northern Arapaho tribes. After several Indian raids, three columns of soldiers (2,675 men in total) were sent to defeat the raiders along the Powder River. All in all, the effort was soundly defeated. The largest battle, variously called the Fetterman Fight, Fetterman Massacre, or Battle of the Hundred Slain saw all 81 soldiers under the command of Captain William J. Fetterman killed by the Allied forces of the Lakota, Cheyenne, and Arapaho tribes under the leadership of Crazy Horse. It was the worst defeat suffered by American forces until the later and more famous Battle of Little Bighorn. The war ended with the Treaty of Fort Laramie in 1868 in which the United States gave up all control of what is now South Dakota west of the Missouri River and created the Great Sioux Reservation. The reason that Red Cloud’s War is often not considered a defeat is that the United States failed to honor its own treaty and reneged within a decade, leading to the Great Sioux War of 1876, in which the Indians were defeated. Many Americans, if they know of these conflicts at all, view them as setbacks rather than defeats. Nonetheless, the tribes of the northern plains successfully defeated the Army of the United States in open warfare, a feat that very few have ever accomplished.

The long forgotten War of 1812 was another conflict that, while not a clear or resounding defeat, was a wholly unsuccessful military venture for those young United States. A relatively small conflict with few major engagements out side the Battle of New Orleans, the conflict is largely overlooked by historians except in Canada where the outcome mattered greatly to the survival of British rule in North America. The causes of the war are vague and disperse: American anger at alleged Royal Navy impressment of American registered sailors and vessels on the high seas (Britain was in the midst of turmoil due the NapoleonIc Wars and the large scale boycott of Britain via the French Continental System), confusion and conflict regarding territorial sovereignty beyond the northern Ohio Valley region and the anger this caused British allied Native American groups, and a renewal of hawkish sentiment among certain members of Congress to make a final sweep of British Crown influence from America. This all led to a rather half hazard war effort on the American behalf, where a great many in Congress were against any such war, seeing it as a ludicrous waste of men, time, and treasure. To Britain it was an annoyance an entire world away from its serious issues with the wars of the French Revolution. Nevertheless the United States were able to raise a relatively sizeable force of men to invade across the Niagara River and further south from Detriot into Upper Canada (modern day Southern Ontario) and Royal Navy and US vessels engaged each other on the Lakes Eire and Ontario. To defend Upper Canada the British had a relatively sufficient number of Redcoat regulars backed up by a significant militia of local Loyalist settlers from Upper Canada. The key point was the English held a significant advantage in leadership coming from the able young General Issac Brock. The American invasion made some headway at first but was then stymied and largely reversed with British/Canadian success in the Battles of Queenston Heights near modern day Hamilton and striking across the frontier to capture Detriot and control Upper Michigan. The US Navy later won control of Lake Erie , resulting in cut off British and Native troops retreating from Detriot, suffering a losing Battle of the Thames in the process (where legendary Native leader and Crown ally Techmesh fell in fighting service to his Redcoat brothers). However any attempt to invade and conquer the Canadas was clearly beyond the scope of the US military at that present time and US forces made no further efforts to do so. The powerful Royal Navy and Marines then launched an assault along the Cheaspeke Bay region, highlighted by the sacking of Washington DC and the burning of the Capitol Building and White House (a popular urban myth was the Presidential manor was intially a more rose colour and repainted white in the reconstruction). This successful British campaign was stopped in a resolute defeat at the Battle of Baltimore. By 1814 Napleon was in chains and Britain could afford to send more seasoned forces to prosecute war against the US. However two major efforts, an invasion of New York via Lake Champlain and the much celebrated Battle of New Orleans (were a young General Andrew Jackson ‘'made his bones’ so to speak) ended in clear American victory. However stalemate reigned and the US, particularly in the highly anti-war New England, was eager to see peace and normalcy returned before more blood was shed and further money squandered. As such the two parties signed the Treaty of Ghent in Belgium in 1815. It largely reaffirmed the status quo that existed prior to the war, with the national frontiers remaining intact and Crown rule reaffirmed in the Canadas. The one major difference was the collapse of the Confederacy of Tribes under Techmesh which resulted from the war. This British sponsored confederation of Native American tribal groups posed a certain obstacle to unfettered US expansion further west of the Ohio Valley. Its demise made Manifest Destiny all the more destined you could say. But the grander objectives of the war were never even remotely possible once the Congress declared itself for war. As well the US suffered humiliations, like the torching of the White House, that would seem near science fiction by today's standards. In this way, and the near 2500 American dead for a complete return to status quo, one could arguably claim this war as a losing and failed endeavour by the United States.

Canadians are frequently taught the US lost the War of 1812 because they didn't conquer British North America.  However, this is a narrow perspective to have.  Truth is the US probably won the War of 1812, or at the very least, they didn't loose it.  My brother and I debate this all the time.  He thinks that because "our side burned Washington and Canada is not an American state " we" won.  I think the Americans won because they achieved their war aims.   After 25 years of arguments over beers, air can say neither one us is going to budge. Americans fought the War of 1812 mainly for the following reasons: trade restrictions brought about by the British war with France; the impressment of US merchant sailors into the Royal Navy; British support for Native American tribes against European American expansion; and outrage over insults to national honor after humiliations on the high seas.   Many historians have argued that annexing Canada was a war aim.  Many US politicians and journalists, mostly in the the North East had no interest in attacking Britain in North American.  The rest were driven by the goal of expelling Britain from North America as they were tired of British interference in westward expansion.  So a strong argument can be made that annexing  Canada wasn't a war aim, it was a means of ending British interference in, the soon to be, American west was.   While the US lost several battles in 1812 and 1813, they were very successful in 1814 and ended the war on high note.  The scored major victories at sea, on the Great Lakes,and in the American South in 1814. The war ended because Britain had just concluded the Napoleonic Wars and was tired and the US was not interesting in continuing the fight. Both sides were eager for peace. No land changed hands as a result of the war.  Britain eased trade restrictions and stopped impressing American sailors.  The US pretty much ended up with a free hand in the American west.  Americans ended a war on a positive note and so they felt national honour was restored.  The only thing they did not do was annex Canada, and as noted above it is debatable if it was a real war aim. So the US clearly obtained 4 out 5 war aims (for some 4 out of 4 aims).  Britain was defending herself, but conceded everything but territory to the US.  So at worst the War of 1812 was draw for the US.  Canadians believe Britain won because Canada was not annexed and many foundational national myths were formed following the war. Readers maybe interested to know that British scholars largely ignore the war as was seen as minor theatre of operations during the Napoleonic War,  American scholars are not overly interested in the war either ( the American Revolution and the Civil War are far more exciting.  Canadians are very interested in the war as it is seen as laying the foundation for unifying Canada in 1867.

Repressive regimes with opposing views to the West came to power and because of the U.S inability to impede the spread, it lost the war to the Soviets. Without over-analyzing the differences between major and minor wars, armed interventions, and violent incidents, here is a quick run-down on the American effort in a number of wars, comparing the reality of goals to possibilities. Victories in major wars, and please note that there were major alliances involved in most of them:  The American Revolution, The Mexican-American War, the American Civil War, the Spanish-American War, World War I, World War II, and The First Iraq War. In all of these the major strategic goals were accomplished and no crippling strategic failures occurred. Draws in major wars:  The War of 1812 and the Korean War.  Contrary to what is apparently taught in Canadian schools, the War of 1812 was fought between the United States of America and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, with the British colonial possessions in what is now Canada as a major battlefield. While there was a faction in the United States that wanted to resolve its issues with the British by conquering Canada, that turned out to be neither achievable or necessary. The national issue that the prompted the United States to declare war was persistent violations of American sovereignty, some of them by British officials based in Upper Canada (modern Ontario), but most by the Royal Navy harassing American shipping and, in one case attacking and seizing control of a major American naval vessel (the Chesapeake–Leopard Affair) as it was leaving port and unable to defend itself. By 1815, neither side had accomplished much militarily--the burning of Washington by a British naval expedition was not a crippling defeat--and both sides agreed to call the war off. While the war itself was an effective draw, the British thereafter respected American sovereignty and the Americans thereafter respected Canadian sovereignty, which benefited both budding nations immensely. Korea was a draw because, while the defeat of the North Korean armies in the summer of 1950 guaranteed the existence of a democratic South Korea for the foreseeable future, the defeat of the United Nations forces by the Chinese in the winter of 1950 guaranteed North Korea's survival and an effectively permanent state of armed truce on the peninsula still in effect 66 years later. Losses in major wars:  Vietnam, the Afghanistan Invasion, and the Second Iraq War. In none of these wars did the Americans ever lose a major ground battle, but, beyond the devastation inflicted on the countries involved, all three were strategic disasters of the first order. The Americans failed in all three cases to support or create governments stable enough to dominate the the national territory, and so all three wars dragged on for years, consuming American resources, demoralizing and inflicting misery on the local population, and leaving the successor governments strategically with the Americans vulnerable to internal and external attack. At the same time, all three wars crippled America's reputation as a "peaceful"--or at least non-imperialist--power that most American administrations had tried to build up over the last two centuries.  Among minor wars, the Filipino-American War is minor only because it was considered an "internal" war by the international community. The loss of life on the Filipino side was horrific, and the leading American imperialist of the era, Theodore Roosevelt, quickly ordered a peaceful resolution once he fully comprehended the extent of it. This war can best be considered a draw. Balanced against the terrible loss of life is the fact that the Filipinos gained domestic sovereignty through their resistance. The Americans kept the Europeans and Japanese imperialists out of the Philippines--at least until 1941--and agreed to a timetable for full Filipino independence.   The American Indian Wars were also considered internal affairs by the United States and the international community and most involved only a few dozen or a hundred or two hundred deaths. Most were military victories for the American army, although some can be considered draws and almost all of them were ended by negotiation to avoid the annihilation of the tribes involved.  Other armed interventions sometimes ended in military defeats (as with the Reagan Era intervention in Lebanon) but did not rise to the level of strategic defeats or "lost wars" as most historians would define them.

Red Cloud's War 1866–1868 fought along the Bozeman Road in present day Wyoming, and Montana. Many skirmishes with one stand-out: the Fetterman Battle December 21, 1866, outside Fort Phil Kearny, just north of present day Buffalo, Wyoming along I-90. Captain Fetterman and all infantry, cavalry, and citizen soldiers were rubbed-out by some of the same warriors who would defeat Custer at the Little Bighorn 10 years later. When all the fighting was finished, the U.S. Government established and ratified the Treaty of 1868 (Ft. Laramie Treaty) in which the U.S. agreed to abandon all its forts built to house troops who were there to protect those traveling along the Bozeman. Red Cloud pressured the U.S. to abandon all the forts BEFORE he would sign the Treaty, so President Grant approved the closing of Forts C.F. Smith, Kearny, and Reno. Most important, this treaty established the Great Sioux Reservation in present day South Dakota west of the Missouri River, including the Black Hills. Spotted Tail's people were granted the area south of the South Platte along the Republican River in Kansas and Nebraska. Also set aside was the “unceeded Indian territory”, which included Wyoming west to the Bighorn Mountains, and south to the North Platte. This territory was for the Lakota to use for summer excursions to hunt, practice their religion (Sun Dance), weddings, and replenish materials. No white man could live, let alone travel, through these regions without permission of the Lakota. Everything changes six years later when a scientific expedition was approved by Grant to explore the Black Hills. The U.S. was suffering a major economic depression, so the underlying and secret factor to this expedition was to prove if the rumors of gold were true. Leading this expedition of 1000 soldiers, civilians, and Indian scouts would be none other than Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer and his 7th Cavalry. Gold was indeed discovered along French Creek just outside of present-day Custer City, South Dakota. The rest is history.

response.answer_text: Yes. It’s important to keep in mind what “losing” means, however. For instance, take the Vietnam war. The people of the United States of America, through their elected government, engaged in war to support South Vietnam. Despite many military victories, and losing less troops, they eventually gave up on their ally and left. North Vietnam received the unwavering support of China and the Soviet Union, and won. Although the US military technically did not get defeated, it could also not defeat the enemy. At no point the North cried uncle and asked for peace. At no point did the US dare invade the North and neutralize them. At this juncture, more or less the same happens in Afghanistan. The US can blast anything into oblivion, but cannot control what goes on much beyond the perimeter of its bases. Another consideration is if the country is better off after the war than the enemy. If you look at modern Germany and Japan, with higher standards of living, better healthcare, better safety nets and safer lives for their average citizen, you could argue they are ultimately the winners. Yes - Vietnam.  I also tend view the war in Korea as 2 separate wars fought back to back. The first between North Korea and the UN (mostly the US) ended in victory for the UN when North Korean forces were crushed and forced out of South Korea in 1950.  The second phase of the war started with what was probably the worst military mistake ever made by the US, the invasion of North Korea. This ill conceived move brought UN (again mostly US) forces near the border of China and North Korea in Late October 1950, right when the possibility of air support was compromised by the onset of winter. The Chinese intervened as they had warned and pushed the UN forces back into South Korea before their advance was halted.  Subsequent counter attacks by UN forces pushed the Chinese forces to a front around the 38th parallel, the dividing line between North and South Korea. There stalemate set it for 2 blood years while negotiations moved at a snale's pace at Panmunjom.  In my view, the first phase of the war was a victory for the UN since North Korean forces were pushed out of South Korea, the second phase of the war was a UN (and US) defeat because UN forces were push out of North Korea by Chinese forces.

Vietnam. Ho Chi Minh, General Giap, and the North Vietnamese (and the Viet Cong and many of the South Vietnamese) got what they fought for. We spent about ten years over there, lost about 57,000 people, had many others wounded and come back partially disabled and traumatized for life in some cases, generated a lot of upset and upheaval back home — and never came close to getting what we went over there and fought for. At the top of the list of the things the Vietnamese were fighting for was to get our guys out of their country, and be left free to make their own choices regarding how to govern themselves (whether free market, socialism in whatever form, or whatever mix in between), and who should govern them. By the time we were ready to sign the cease-fire in 1973, we could hardly wait to get our guys out of there, and leave the “non-Communist”, “democratic”, but still badly corrupt and unpopular and anything-but-democratic government that we ourselves had set up back in the 50s, and had been over there fighting unsuccessfully to support, on its own — which was exactly what our adversaries wanted and had been fighting for. I don’t mean to sound unpatriotic or denigrate the efforts or sacrifices of our guys who served, but I can’t exactly call that a win for us. Lesson learned: some things, you just can’t force, now matter how powerful and mighty and rich you are, and no matter how powerless and weak and lacking in resources your adversary may seem by comparison. They have certainly lost major battles & it started early. In the battle of Penobscot Bay, at the mouth of the Bagaduce river, 700 British Marines, accompanied by a sloop of war & two small supply ships occupied a ruined fort on the Majabigwaduce Peninsula, to block American forces from proceeding up the river systems into Canada. The 1000 strong Massachusetts Militia, plus a 100 man artillery unit commanded by Paul Revere, a Company of Continental Army Marines and a fleet of 44 ships, including 26 warships attacked the British position. In a battle lasting 3 weeks the British Marines defeated the American forces, killing, wounding or capturing 476 American soldiers, destroying every single American ship in the process (~ 25% of the American Navy) & suffering only 86 casualties. It was the largest US Naval defeat until Pearl Harbour.

War is not a game with ultimate winners and losers. It is merely a continuation of the political process, whereby two or more sides test their commitment to the ideas that they previously believed to be non-negotiable.  During the course of war political aims often change. Prosecuting a war has costs -- both in lives and in materiel. In paying those costs, a country has to continually ask themselves if what they are currently trying to achieve is worth the cost of continuing on  If its not, hostilities are reassigned or else end in retreat or surrender.

With the U.S. poverty rate at 17% when the initiatives introduced by Johnson were instituted, the years since have seen the poverty rate sink as low as 11% but then climb as high as 15%, staying between those percentages ever since. Today 47% of taxpayers do not even earn enough to have to pay income tax, and the gap between rich and poor is greater than any other time in the nation’s history. The groups that benefited the most from Johnson’s programs (Medicare and Medicaid especially) were the elderly and those under 18 years old, while the poverty rate among those ages 18-64 years has basically remained the same. At an investment of $15 trillion, the return has been low and the achievements modest. For the very little gain, it has been catastrophic to the national budget. Over 46 million Americans remain in poverty, the highest number in U.S. history.
